questions.text: Which of the following muscle is known as the safety muscle of larynx and what is the action of this muscle?
questions.solution:
Posterior cricoarytenoid is the only muscle which opens the vocal cords (abducts the vocal cords) thus helping in respiration hence it is also known as the safety muscle of the larynx .

Option B : Aryepiglottic muscle closes laryngeal inlet along with oblique arytenoids.

Option C : Cricothyroid muscle is the tensor of vocal cord along with thyroarytenoid

Option D : Interarytenoid causes adduction of vocal cords along with cricothyroid, and Thyroarytenoid muscle.

key takeaway :

Posterior cricoarytenoid is the only muscle which opens the vocal cords (abducts the vocal cords) thus helping in respiration hence it is also known as safety muscle of larynx .

questions.text: The picture given below is a cut section of cavity of larynx. All of the following structures in the cavity of larynx is correctly matched except?
questions.solution:
The cavity of the larynx from above downwards consists of the following:

Option D : Inlet of larynx: The inlet lies in between the suprahyoid epiglottis anteriorly, the two Aryepiglottic folds on both the sides and arytenoids and inter arytenoid area posteriorly.

Option A : Vestibule: This is the part of laryngeal cavity in between the two quadrangular membranes.

Rima vestibuli: This is the part of the cavity in between the two false vocal cords.

Option B : Ventricle: This is the part of cavity in between the false vocal cord above and true vocal cords below. This goes laterally to form sac like structure known as saccule.

Option C : Rima glottidis: This is the part of cavity in between the two true vocal cords.

Sub glottis: The part of cavity below the glottis in between the two cricovocal membranes and cricoid cartilage is known as subglottis.

questions.text: All of the following features differentiate an infant larynx from an adult larynx except?
questions.solution:
Features of infant larynx:

  • Epiglottis is omega shaped and thyroid cartilage is flat
  • Narrowest part is subglottis.
  • Cartilage are soft
  • Sub mucosal is loose
  • It is located higher opposite to C2 and C3.

Features of adult larynx:

  • Epiglottis is leaf shaped and thyroid cartilage is angulated.
  • Narrowest part is glottis
  • Cartilage are ossified
  • Sub mucosal is less and dense.
  • It lies lower at level of C5 C6.

key takeaway :

The other name of paraglottic space is called space of tucker. The other name of pre epiglottic space is the space of boyer. ( Option D )

questions.text: A anaesthetic was performing the procedure of superior laryngeal nerve block. Picture given below. What will be the landmark he will use for superior laryngeal nerve block?
questions.solution:
The larynx is supplied by the vagus nerve. The vagus nerve gives 2 branches to larynx The superior laryngeal nerve and the recurrent laryngeal nerve.

Superior laryngeal nerve after arising from the Inferior ganglion of vagus just below the base of skull.

The superior laryngeal nerve descends down and in the neck at the level of Greater cornu of hyoid bone. It gives off two branches

External laryngeal nerve as the name suggests it lies externally deep to the superior thyroid artery and supplies the cricothyroid muscle which is the only intrinsic muscle of larynx lying externally.

Internal laryngeal nerve: pierces thyrohyoid membrane along with the superior laryngeal artery passes between the middle and inferior constrictor and gives sensory supply to the larynx and hypopharynx above the vocal cords.

key takeaway :

The superior laryngeal nerve divide at the level of Greater cornu of hyoid bone. So it can be used as a landmark for blocks.

questions.text: A 4-year-old male child presented with complain of fever, inspiratory stridor, and barking cough. His X ray neck AP view was performed. Picture of the x-ray is given below. Which of the following is true about the condition?
questions.solution:
The sign shown in the x-ray given above is steeple sign. It is seen in laryngo-tracheo-bronchitis or croup.

It involves larynx mainly subglottis, leading to subglottis oedema and progress to trachea and bronchi.

Clinical features includes gradual onset fever, barking cough, hoarseness and stridor.

Diagnosis is confirmed by x-ray neck AP view which shows subglottis and upper trachea to be narrowed.

It appears like inverted V resembling steeple of a church. Hence known as steeple sign or pencil tip sign.

Management includes humidification, decongestant, local and systemic steroids. Intubation or tracheostomy if necessary.

Other Options : S/o Acute Epiglottis.

Image reference: Radiopedia.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presented with complain of severe pain and hoarseness of voice. Endoscopic picture of larynx is given below, The picture shows mouse nibbled appearance of the vocal cords, what is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical features and pictures shown above the diagnosis in this case is TB laryngitis.

Primary TB laryngitis is very rare. It usually develops secondary to pulmonary TB.

Clinical features include odynophagia. Painful deglutition is due to inflammation of Epiglottis.

Signs: The earliest sign is hyperemia of vocal cords and posterior commissure.

Arytenoid becomes very swollen known as mammillated arytenoids.

There are multiple ulcers on the vocal cords giving it mouse nibbled appearance.

Epiglottis becomes very swollen giving it a turban Epiglottis appearance.

Management is anti tubercular therapy.

Key Takeaway:

TB Larynx - 2 P & 2 M

  • Posterior & Painful
  • Mouse Nibble Cords & Mammillated Arytenoids

questions.text: A 25-year-old female patient presented with gradually increasing respiratory distress since 4 days. She gives history of hospitalization and mechanical ventilation with orotracheal intubation for 2 weeks. Now she is diagnosed as having severe laryngotracheal stenosis. Next step in management is ?
questions.solution:
Development of fibrosis and strictures leading to narrowing of the lumen of subglottis and trachea is known as subglottic stenosis.

It can be congenital and acquired. Most common cause of acquired stenosis is prolonged intubation. It causes pressure necrosis and fibrosis of subglottic mucosa.

It can be divided into 4 grades:

Grade 1 - 0 to 50 %

Grade 2 - 51 to 70%

Grade 3 - 71 to 99%

Grade 4 - no detectable lumen.

Management: In Grade 1 and 2 are managed by laser excision or endoscopic dilation is done. (Option A & C)

In grade 3 and 4 tracheostomy is performed to maintain airway. Laryngotracheal reconstruction procedures like Resection and end to end anastomosis is performed in severe cases. (Option D)

Option B - Steroid has no role in management of Subglottic stenosis.

key takeaway :

Subglottic stenosis Management :

Grade 1 / 2 - Laser Excision & Endoscopic Dilation

Grade 3 / 4 - Resection & Anastomosis.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presented with pain during swallowing and noisy breathing. Examination showed a toxic, tachypneic child with inspiratory stridor and drooling of saliva. The x-ray soft tissue neck lateral view is shown. The most probable diagnosis is ?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical features and picture the diagnosis here is Acute epiglottitis.

It is sometimes also known as Acute supraglottic laryngitis. It is rapidly progressing condition caused most commonly by Group A beta haemolytic streptococcus.

Commonly affects child between 2 to 6 years of age. Child presents with Acute onset of fever and inspiratory stridor. Usually odynophagia and drooling of saliva also develops.

Vocal cords are normal so cry is normal and stridor is inspiratory.

X-ray soft tissue neck shows epiglottis to be swollen and appears like thumb hence known as thumb sign.

Management is by antibiotics beta lactams is the drug of choice. Steroids at times added for a short period of time.

Option B: Croup Caused by parainfluenza virus mainly involves Subglottic giving Steeple Sign.

Option C: Retropharyngeal abscess

Option D: Prevertebral Absecess

Key Takeaway:

Image Reference: Radiopedia.

questions.text: A 6-month-old baby presented with complain of stridor. The stridor was inspiratory in nature and get aggravated on crying and sleeping in supine position, and it gets relieved on making child prone. Laryngoscopic examination was done picture given below. Which of the following is not true about this condition?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical features and picture the diagnosis is laryngomalacia.

It is the most common congenital anomaly of the larynx and also the most common cause of stridor in infants. (Option A)

Main presentation is of stridor which is inspiratory in nature and peaks around 6 months of age. The stridor worsens on crying and in supine position and improves in prone position. (Option C)

Laryngoscopy examination reveals curled up Epiglottis or omega shaped Epiglottis. The arytenoids and the AE folds appears flabby. (Option B)

Management: As the larynx grows all the redundant tissue is taken up and the stridor disappears by 2 years of age. So management is by conservative by reassurance.

Rarely excision of excessive redundant tissue is done called supraglottoplasty. (Option D)

key takeaway :

Laryngomalacia management is by conservative by reassurance as the larynx grows, all the redundant tissue is taken up and the stridor disappears by 2 years of age. Rarely excision of excessive redundant tissue is done called supraglottoplasty.

Image reference: Respiratory medicine today website.

questions.text: A one day old child presented with a weak cry since birth and biphasic stridor. Incomplete canalisation was considered. Most common defect would be at?
questions.solution:
Stridor is the abnormal high, or low pitched sound due to turbulent air flow through obstructed larynx, trachea or large bronchi.

In Glottic pathology, the cry will not be normal and stridor will be biphasic. Incomplete canalisation means that the child is having laryngeal web.

Biphasic stridor will also be present in the subglottic pathology but cry will be normal. ( Option B )

In supraglottic condition the stridor will be inspiratory and cry will be normal. ( Option A )

Educational Objective :

questions.text: A 1-month-old child presented with complain of weak cry since birth and biphasic stridor. His examination findings are given in the picture below. Which of the following statements about this condition is not true?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical picture and symptoms the diagnosis in this case is Laryngeal web.

Laryngeal webs are formed because of incomplete canalization of the laryngotracheal groove during the development. ( Option A )

Most common site of development of these webs is anterior commissure of the vocal cords. ( Option B )

Child presents with weak cry and in severe cases stridor is present. However Laryngeal webs are not the most common cause of stridor in new-born and infants.

Laryngomalacia is the most common cause of stridor in new-born and infants. ( Option C )

It is managed by division of the web by using co2 laser and a Silastic keel Is secured between the vocal cords at the anterior commissure. ( Option D )

key takeaway :

Laryngeal web :

Defect - Incomplete Canalization

Site - Anterior Commisure of vocal cords

Presentation - Weak Cry since birth.

Management - Co2 laser

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient underwent Total thyroidectomy. Following the surgery patient developed respiratory stridor. Endoscopic examination of vocal cords was done. Picture Is shown below. What is the probable cause of stridor and what is its appropriate management?
questions.solution:
The above endoscopic picture shows that both the vocal cords are completely in the median position, which is suggestive of bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy.

Most probable cause of bilateral RLN palsy is iatrogenic trauma induced during Total thyroidectomy.

The treatment of Bilateral RLN palsy includes immediate Tracheostomy. Followed by Lateralization of vocal cords which is done in type 2 thyroplasty.

Type 1 thyroplasty - Medialization of vocal cords.

Type 2 thyroplasty - Lateralization of vocal cords.

Type 3 thyroplasty- Shortening of vocal cords.

Type 4 thyroplasty- lengthening of vocal cords.

Mnemonic : MLSL.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient went to a protest in the university. Following it he developed a complaint of hoarseness of voice. He was taken for endoscopic examination. Endoscopic picture is given below. He should be managed by ?
questions.solution:
The picture shown above is of vocal cord polyp.

They are benign solitary swelling of >3mm arising from the free edge of the true vocal cord. It is due to sudden voice abuse.

It is unilateral and pedunculated and present at the junction of anterior 1/3rd and posterior 2/3rd. Clinical presentation is hoarseness of voice.

It has to be always excised by Microlaryngoscopic surgery. Followed by speech therapy.

questions.text: A 16-year-old male patient who is a trumpet player presents as external swelling in the anterior part of the neck on the left side. The swelling was increasing in size on blowing the trumpet. Which of the following is true about the condition ?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical picture and the endoscopy the diagnosis here is laryngocele.

Any chronic increase in the transglottic pressure as in glass blowers , trumpet players or weight lifters. Leads to enlargement of the saccule .

Laryngocele can be intrinsic and extrinsic. It pierces thyrohyoid membrane. ( Option B )

The external swelling increases on Valsalva.

On compression of the swelling the air escapes into the larynx creating a hissing sound it is known as Bryce sign. ( Option D ). Boyce sign seen in Zenker Diverticulum.

Omega Shaped Epiglottis seen in laryngomalacia ( Option C )

Management is done by excision through open neck approach.

key takeaway :

Laryngocele

  • Enlargement of Saccule
  • Pierces thyrohyoid membrane.
  • Bryce Sign
  • Managed with Excision.

Image reference: Laryngopedia.

questions.text: A 18-year-old male presented with complain of persistence of high pitched voice like that of females. The patient have achieved puberty. On examination the vocal cords were mobile and normal. What is management in this case?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical condition and findings the diagnosis in this case appears to be Puberphonia.

It is also known as Mutational falsetto. At puberty the high pitched voice of a boy changes to the low pitch voice of an adult male due to lengthening and relaxation of vocal cords.

If the low pitch voice fails to develop, the adult male continues to have a high pitched voice. This is known as puberphonia. It is seen in introverts and emotionally insecure males.

Management: Type 3 thyroplasty is performed in such cases which causes shortening and relaxation of the vocal cords.

Key Takeaway:

Thyroplasty Types: PLaSTy

  1. Proximalization / Medialization
  2. Lateralisation
  3. Shortening - Puberphonia
  4. Tightening / Lengthening - Androphonia

questions.text: A teacher presented with complain of tiredness of voice and hoarseness. On Laryngoscopic examination, keyhole appearance of glottis is present. Which of the following is true in this case?

Keyhole appearance in laryngoscopy is seen in Phonaesthesia.

It is a condition in which there is weakness of phonatory muscles.

Mainly involving 2 groups. The Thyroarytenoid which is an adductor of the vocal cords. ( Option D )

An elliptical gap is seen. The Interarytenoid forms a triangular gap.

If both the muscles are involved a keyhole appearance is seen. ( Option B )

Management is voice rest. ( Option C )

  • Interarytenoid - Triangular

questions.text: A 30 year female patient presented with complain of hoarseness of voice. Her endoscopic picture is given below. Which of the following statement is true for this condition?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical picture and symptoms the diagnosis in this case is pachydermia laryngis / contact ulcer of larynx which occurs at posterior 1/3rd of vocal cords. (Option A)

It occurs due to prolonged voice abuse when the two vocal process of arytenoids is forcefully rubbed against each other, it leads to heaping of the epithelium. (Option B)

The heaping causes saucer shaped indentation on the medial edge of other vocal process which appears like an ulcer hence known as contact ulcer.

It is not a premalignant condition. It is not a true ulcer since there is no breach of the epithelium, it is just an indentation.

Management: They usually regress by voice rest and speech therapy. (Option D)

Microlaryngeal surgery is done if they do not regress. The biopsy shows hyperkeratosis.

key takeaway :

Contact Ulcer Larynx

  • At posterior 1/3rd of Vocal Cord
  • Due to Prolonged Voice Abuse
  • Not Premalignant, managed with Voice rest and Speech Therapy.

Image reference: Laryngopedia.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient teacher by profession presented with complain of hoarseness of voice. Her endoscopic picture is given below. All of the following are true about this condition except?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical picture and symptoms, the diagnosis in this case is vocal cord polyp.

It is a benign solitary swelling arising from the free edge of the true vocal cord. It is due to a sudden voice abuse (eg. Shouting).

It is unilateral and pedunculated (Option A) and is present at the site of maximum vibration of vocal cords that is at the junction of anterior 1/3rd and posterior 2/3rd. (Option B)

It is presented with hoarseness of voice since it is unilateral, the vibratory frequency of the both the vocal cords is different, leading to diplophonia (double voice). (Option C)

Management: it has to be always excised by Microlaryngeal surgery MLS . Followed by speech therapy. (Option D)
